text:
Reliable source
New Zealand Holds Bird Election of the Year üê¶
All for real - with campaign headquarters, campaigning and ballot boxing
06 Nov 2019, 13:37 by The Guardian
Since 2005, the bird of the year has been selected in New Zealand to attract attention to rare and endangered species. Over time, the vote, which is overseen by the Royal Society for the Protection of Forests and Birds, has become increasingly widespread, and it has become much more serious. If in 2005 the number of voters was 900 people, then by 2015 it had grown to 28 thousand, and in 2018 - to 48 thousand.
Last year, the title of ‚Äúbird of the year‚Äù was won by Kerer - ‚Äúdrunk pigeon‚Äù who eats fermented fruits, which is why he is drunk and falls from the trees. He scored 5833 votes, and the struggle for them was not easy.



The "election campaigns" of birds are carried out by individual enthusiasts or entire staffs. Among the "political technologies" used are Tinder profiles, tattoos, and celebrity support. For example, Stephen Fry called for a vote for the cacapo owl parrot.



There was a place in the election history even for talk of foreign intervention - they did not blame the Russians, but the Australians. In 2018, more than 300 votes were cast from the Australian IP address for kawau, a cormorant bird. The throw-in was quickly discovered, the voices were nullified.



In 2018, Taiko the black petrel was supported by the current Prime Minister of the country, Jacinda Ardern. And the supporters of the buller's gull in the 2017 election during the campaign even allowed themselves to offend the kiwi, calling it ‚Äúfat flightless ******‚Äù.
Kimberly Collins, who worked as an election coordinator in the past, believes that such incidents and fraud attempts are not really a cause for concern, but rather a sign of concern for New Zealanders: ‚ÄúThis is more like a friendly skirmish, but on the whole we warmly support our birds and we don‚Äôt want to witness the extinction of one species in our lifetime. ‚Äù
Since 2019, the voting system has been changed, now you can cast your vote not for just one applicant, but choose up to five species of birds. ‚ÄúIt was too difficult for people to choose only one bird,‚Äù said Meghan Habschner, spokeswoman for the Royal Society for the Conservation of Forests and Birds. However, she added, the campaign strategy has now changed. ‚ÄúFor example, supporters of different subspecies of penguins team up to get‚Äú five ticks for penguins, ‚Äùshe said.



Predicting the election results is quite difficult: in the entire history of the vote, not one species of bird was able to win twice. Last year‚Äôs winner‚Äôs deal with Kerer is bad: at the time of writing, he wasn‚Äôt even in the top 5.
Who this time will be the "bird of the year" will be known on November 11. Vote here.
